description: Not captive against his will. Where did he buy those leg bands?

Meet a Kea.  Keas are the world's only alpine parrots.  They are large (body as big as a macaw), very intelligent, very playful, and very bold.  I was thrilled to spot my first one in a tree at one of our roadside scenic overlook stops -- and even more thrilled when it came down for a visit.  Unfortunately they seem to be accustomed to handouts.  They also like to play and explore -- shoelaces, pockets, car weatherstripping --and can be very destructive.  Some of the behavior may be looking for food, but some of it is clearly pure play.  Parrots love things with interesting textures (such as rubber weatherstripping!).

More keas & kea antics tomorrow.  Meanwhile, this is the first one I saw.  This one had something wrong with it's right foot, but it knows how handsome it is anyway.

This is the car belonging to [rented by?] the intrepid photographer in Ooh, look, a Kea!, waiting for the green light on the inland side of the one-way Homer Tunnel. He thought it was great fun when the Kea started exploring his car. We had to warn him that the bird would shred his weatherstripping, given half a chance. Sure enough, that's what the bird was after! The driver put a stop to the proceedings before it did too much damage. Keas are the world's only alpine parrots, and are found only in the Southern Alps of New Zealand. They are very large (as you can see), very intelligent, very playful, and very bold. Unfortunately they seem to be accustomed to handouts. They also like to play and explore -- shoelaces, pockets, car weatherstripping -- and can be very destructive Some of the behavior may be looking for food, but some of it is clearly pure play. Parrots love things with interesting textures -- such as rubber weatherstripping!
Arthurs Pass, above viaduct, c 700m
Kea (Nestor notabilis), the smart, mischevious native mountain parrot. Captive animal at Willowbank Wildlife Reserve, Christchurch, Canterbury, New Zealand

One of a gang of juvenile kea romping about on the mountain side around the Broken River Skifield. They seemed just as curious about us as we were about them.

(060410#037)

tag_list: adaptation, anthropogenic, skiing, Mt. Hutt, Kea
description: Apparently these guys hang around Mt. Hutt ski area quite a bit. They perhaps have even increased in numbers (at least in annoying the groundskeepers) in recent years. Old hat to many that frequent Mt. Hutt, but nice to see for us new to the islands. The two in the parking lot were dirty from all the fresh mud. A flock of ~12 took off and were making a ruckus while we were going down the bunny slope!
A kea checks out Lisa Couet and the rest of the Ecol202 class along the Dobson Nature Walk, Arthurs Pass National Park.

tag_list: Arthurs Pass, Nestor notabilis, Nestor, alpine parrot, parrot, kea
description:
Notorious for their sometimes destructive curiosity, kea are highly intelligent birds and, especially juveniles like this bird, love investigating new things with their razor sharp beak, such as cars! It is this curiosity and willingness to test anything for its edibility which has probably helped it survive in its alpine environment.
A protected species of alpine parrot endemic to New Zealand. 
Found in forested and alpine regions of the South Island. 
Little is known about their population except that it seems to be in decline (c. 5000 birds). 
The Kea was once killed for bounty as it occasionally preyed on livestock, especially sheep. It is now known that only a few kea learn this trick and most kea seen on dead sheep are scavanging an already dead carcass.
It only received full protection in 1986. 
Kea nest in burrows or crevices among the roots of trees. They are regarded as one of the most intelligent birds in the world, and for their insatiable curiosity, both vital to their survival in a harsh mountain environment. Kea can solve logical puzzles, such as pushing and pulling things in a certain order to get to food, and will work together to achieve a certain objective. 
The Kea is a large parrot about 48 cm (19 in) long and weighing about 1 kg (2.2 lb). It has mostly olive-green plumage with a grey beak having a long narrow curved upper beak. The adult has dark-brown irises, and the cere, eyerings, and legs are grey. It has orange feathers on the undersides of its wings. The feathers on the sides of its face are dark olive-brown, feathers on its back and rump are orange-red, and some of the outer wing feathers are dull-blue. It has a short and broad bluish-green tail with a black tip. Feather shafts project at the tip of the tail and the undersides of the inner tail feathers have yellow-orange transverse stripes. The male is about 5% longer than the female, and the male's upper beak is 12â€“14% longer than the female's. Juveniles generally resemble adults, but have yellow eyerings and cere, an orange-yellow lower beak, and grey-yellow legs. Kea range from lowland river valleys and coastal forests of the westcoast up to the alpine regions of the South Island such as Arthur's Pass and Aoraki/Mount Cook National Park, closely associated throughout its range with the southern beech (Nothofagus) forests in the alpine ridge. Apart from occasional vagrants, Kea are not found in the North Island, although fossil evidence suggests a population lived there over 10,000 years ago. The population was estimated at between 1,000 and 5,000 individuals in 1986, contrasting with another estimate of 15,000 birds in 1992. Both estimates depend heavily upon the assumptions made. The Kea's widespread distribution at low density across inaccessible areas prevents accurate estimates. Their notorious urge to explore and manipulate, combined with strong attraction to anything new or different in their environment makes this bird a pest for residents and an attraction for tourists. Called "the clown of the mountains", it will investigate backpacks, boots or even cars, often causing damage or flying off with smaller items. People commonly encounter wild Kea at South Island ski areas. The Kea are attracted by the prospect of food scraps. Their curiosity leads them to peck and carry away unguarded items of clothing or to pry apart rubber parts of carsâ€”to the entertainment and annoyance of human observers. They are often described as "cheeky". A Kea has even been reported to have made off with a Scottish man's passport while he was visiting Fiordland, and theft of car keys, leaving tourists stranded, is a story that has passed into legend.
Mortality is high among young Kea, with less than 40% surviving their first year. The median lifespan of a wild subadult Kea has been estimated at 5 years, based on the proportion of Kea seen again in successive seasons in Arthur's Pass, and allowing for some emigration to surrounding areas. Around 10% of the local Kea population were expected to be over 20 years of age. The oldest known captive Kea was 50 years old in 2008. At least one observer has reported that the Kea is polygynous, with one male attached to multiple females. The same source noted that there was a surplus of females. Kea are social and live in groups of up to 13 birds. Isolated individuals do badly in captivity but respond well to mirror images. In one study, nest sites occur at a density of 1 per 4.4 kmÂ_. The breeding areas are most commonly in Southern Beech (Nothofagus) forests, located on steep mountain sides. Breeding at heights of 1600 m above sea level and higher, it is one of the few parrot species in the world to regularly spend time above tree line. Nest sites are usually positioned on the ground underneath large beech trees, in rock crevices or dug burrows between roots. They are accessed by tunnels leading back 1 m to 6 m into a larger chamber, which is furnished with lichens, moss, ferns and rotting wood. The laying period starts in July and reaches into January. Two to five white eggs are laid, with an incubation time of around 21 days, and a brooding period of 94 days.  An omnivore, the Kea feeds on more than 40 plant species beetle larva, other birds (including shearwater chicks) and mammals (including sheep and rabbits). It has been observed breaking open shearwater nests to feed on the chicks after hearing the chicks in their nests. The Kea is classed as Nationally Endangered in the New Zealand Threat Classification System and Vulnerable in the IUCN Red List.
There's a few kea floating around in the valley. I've watched them in many months over the space of about 10 years. This photo is taken during mid-summer.

Juveniles generally resemble adults, but have yellow eyerings and cere, an orange-yellow lower beak, and grey-yellow legs. Kea range from lowland river valleys and coastal forests of the westcoast up to the alpine regions of the South Island such as Arthur's Pass and Aoraki/Mount Cook National Park, closely associated throughout its range with the southern beech (Nothofagus) forests in the alpine ridge. Apart from occasional vagrants, Kea are not found in the North Island, although fossil evidence suggests a population lived there over 10,000 years ago. The population was estimated at between 1,000 and 5,000 individuals in 1986, contrasting with another estimate of 15,000 birds in 1992. Both estimates depend heavily upon the assumptions made. The Kea's widespread distribution at low density across inaccessible areas prevents accurate estimates. Their notorious urge to explore and manipulate, combined with strong attraction to anything new or different in their environment makes this bird a pest for residents and an attraction for tourists. Called "the clown of the mountains", it will investigate backpacks, boots or even cars, often causing damage or flying off with smaller items. People commonly encounter wild Kea at South Island ski areas. The Kea are attracted by the prospect of food scraps. Their curiosity leads them to peck and carry away unguarded items of clothing or to pry apart rubber parts of carsâ€”to the entertainment and annoyance of human observers. They are often described as "cheeky". A Kea has even been reported to have made off with a Scottish man's passport while he was visiting Fiordland, and theft of car keys, leaving tourists stranded, is a story that has passed into legend.
Mortality is high among young Kea, with less than 40% surviving their first year. The median lifespan of a wild subadult Kea has been estimated at 5 years, based on the proportion of Kea seen again in successive seasons in Arthur's Pass, and allowing for some emigration to surrounding areas. Around 10% of the local Kea population were expected to be over 20 years of age. The oldest known captive Kea was 50 years old in 2008. At least one observer has reported that the Kea is polygynous, with one male attached to multiple females. The same source noted that there was a surplus of females. Kea are social and live in groups of up to 13 birds. Isolated individuals do badly in captivity but respond well to mirror images. In one study, nest sites occur at a density of 1 per 4.4 kmÂ_. The breeding areas are most commonly in Southern Beech (Nothofagus) forests, located on steep mountain sides. Breeding at heights of 1600 m above sea level and higher, it is one of the few parrot species in the world to regularly spend time above tree line. Nest sites are usually positioned on the ground underneath large beech trees, in rock crevices or dug burrows between roots. They are accessed by tunnels leading back 1 m to 6 m into a larger chamber, which is furnished with lichens, moss, ferns and rotting wood. The laying period starts in July and reaches into January. Two to five white eggs are laid, with an incubation time of around 21 days, and a brooding period of 94 days.  An omnivore, the Kea feeds on more than 40 plant species beetle larva, other birds (including shearwater chicks) and mammals (including sheep and rabbits). It has been observed breaking open shearwater nests to feed on the chicks after hearing the chicks in their nests. The Kea is classed as Nationally Endangered in the New Zealand Threat Classification System and Vulnerable in the IUCN Red List.

It only received full protection in 1986.

description: Heard calling

Adult and juvenile kea at the lookout above the viaduct.

We watched one kea glide down to the main road and wait for a car to arrive, jump on its roof, and surf it back up to the carpark, hunched down with its head forward. It all looked well practised. Kea car surfing!
place_guess: Devil's Slide lookout, Arthur's Pass National Park, West Coast, New Zealand

Heard flying overhead
Nestor notabilis (kea). Ridgeline north of Mt Fyffe, Seaward Kaikoura Range. Â© Murray Dawson

tag_list: Porter's Pass, Kea
Arthur's Pass, alpine parrot, parrot, Nestor notabilis, Kea
description: This series of shots is a sample from a bigger series showing a group of juvenile kea at the Otira Viaduct Lookout having fun fighting over a 'toy', a piece of bright pink foam, the sort that's used as a protector on things like ski racks, boat trailers etc. The game comprised of one bird grabbing the foam and flying to the top of a bush or rock. The others then had turns at trying to knock the 'king of the rock' off its perch and grabbing the foam, whereas that bird would then take the high ground and the others in turn would try to steal the foam. This game went on for quite some time before an adult bird flew overhead and called the youngsters away.
On the moraine wall SE of the lake (just by the outlet)

tag_list: Arthurs Pass
Arthur's Pass, Otira Valley, alpine parrot, parrot, Nestor notabilis, Kea
description: This series of shots shows two behaviours of juvenile kea, one feeding naturally on Coprosma berries (in this case, I think, Coprosma rugosa), the other showing the notorious car dismantling behaviour! When I was with DOC I wrote media releases about a study which showed that young kea are the primary vandals and their destructive curiosity can be greatly reduced by preventing access to human food so they have to spend time and energy foraging naturally. I was intrigued that different birds had different techniques for taking the Coprosma berries with some using the lower mandible as a scoop/net to catch berries falling from the branch as they were knocked off by the upper mandible. But other birds delicately picked one berry at a time between the tips of their bill.
There were Kea sitting on the roof of a building near the entrance for Avalanche Peak. They were calling to one another and causing general mischief by picking at cars.
place_guess: Arthur's Pass village, Canterbury, New Zealand

description: A group of juvenile kea were gathered at the lookout at Death's Corner.
place_guess: Devil's Slide lookout (Death's corner), Arthur's Pass National Park, West Coast, New Zealand

description: Three Kea flying high seen (and heard!) from track between Cedar Flats Hut and carpark.
One Kea flying high late evening above Crystal Biv in the Toaroha Valley
Seven Kea flying high at Fox Glacier, seen from glacier lookout, looking up the glacier
Two Juvenile Kea hopping around on the road to Gillespies Beach just before sunset, watched them for about 20 minutes, another one was hanging around in the trees above occasionally calling out.

description: stopped for a tea break and 1 kea said hello!

tag_list: Kea
description:
At the summit came across a group of keas. I was so thrilled! Sorry, the photos aren't very clear. 

On Sat. (6th. April) got to the '1hr to the summit' sign) and heard them, but couldn't see them. It was late arvo and didn't have time to climb to the summit. (I would have run out of daylight) and had to come down. (I accidently deleted all of my photos from my SLR from that day. I almost cried!) Thankfully I still had some photos from the other camera I took along.

Then on this day (Sun. 13th. April) made it all the way to the summit.
Calls coming from face for most of the day. Three seen flying from area in late afternoon.
Cheeky, on the verandah of the Crow Hut in Arthur's Pass.  Happy to explore the mouth feel of my hut-shoes too.
place_guess: Crow Hut, Arthurs Pass National Park

description: Cheeky young Kea at the summit of Avalanche Peak, inspecting and attempting to nibble on every unattended piece of trampers' gear.

Juvenile Kea spent quite some time turning over rocks to look for bugs - finally found some small insect. Also ate a leaf or two.  Showed quite a knack for clearing any moss or grass around each 10-15cm stone, as required, then levering up and tipping over the stone to check underneath. Wasn't at all fussed with me squatting next to it observing.
As we stood outside the car in the hail taking pics of kea sheltered *under* the car, it became clear which species was more intelligent.
place_guess: Arthurs Pass, Westland, West Coast, New Zealand

description:
flock of 9 feeding in tussock/ herbfield above road, late afternoon

none banded
lower end of Waterfall Flat
A banded adult kea sheltered under our car from the driving rain.

description: A juvenile kea sheltered under our car from the driving rain.

description: 2 of them,playing with little rocks,pretty tame
In the garden next to the train station.
Kea (Nestor notabilis) flying outside the Arthur's Pass Store

tag_list: leg band
description:
Hey!  Turn your back for a second...  

Second photo: that's not food, it's some random trash from the parking lot.  This bird was busy investigating and tearing apart all of it.  

Both of its legs were banded with E.
Solitary bird flying SW at low altitude.

tag_list: Esk River
description: A flock of five noisy kea passed over hut.
Kea at Temple Basin ski lodge. They only came to the lodge at sunrise and sunset, making it hard to photograph them.
Two adults seen several times over the day / night

Those pictures were taken in 2013. We had a short tour in Milford Sound. When we stopped for looking around, those birds came and stood on the top of cars. They seem unfriendly. 

In general, I described it as a black parrot or a eagle. But I never saw it before. I couldn't remmember if its were sounding. 

We didnt know where were they from. Whether they were wild or not.

Just a record shot, taken with a 100mm macro. The most seen at one time in this area over the 10 or so days I was there was 5. Most days a couple were heard. Although they twice landed as close as a few m away, they showed little real interest in us. No gear was harmed :)
Casual observation of 4 Kea birds. They were friendly.

One bird sighted, but logging contractors on site reported an adult pair with 4 juveniles had been damaging some of their machinery over the past few months. They also reported a pair of falcons were often seen harassing the kea.

tag_list: Kea
description:
Actually heard them. But couldn't see them. Small group of them high in the trees on the mountain.

So nice to hear their calls again.
The date might be out by a day or 2, but not more. This was one of several kea eating from rubbish and crumbs at Arthur's pass. Not the best diet for them, I guess.
yellow rings around their eyes indicating youth
fairly sure it,s a kea feather. Bird in the vacinity and it,s plumage looked similar

description: We saw a couple of Kea as near our GatorWaka when we were leaving Arthurs Pass.
